parts.title: Growth Strategies for Startups - Initial Tactics and Their Implementation
parts.body: In the book "100 Days of Growth," the authors discuss various marketing strategies to help startups grow. They highlight tactics like giving away free company t-shirts to enhance brand awareness and customer loyalty. Another strategy is sending a personalized welcome email to new customers, offering a friendly digital "hi," much like a mom-and-pop shop's welcome. The authors also suggest the VIP Beta Launch, enticing prospects with exclusive access, and using Help A Reporter Out (HARO) for free publicity. Crafting an education-focused email series demonstrates your willingness to help potential customers and communicate value through a promise-oriented headline on your site, catching visitors' interest in mere seconds.

parts.title: Building Credibility with Weekly Roundups
parts.body: Blog regularly for business credibility. Use Weekly Roundup posts to build your reputation by sharing industry content and prove you have the right ideas and solutions. Curate and share quality posts from others to boost your standing in your sector.

parts.title: Reactivating Inactive Users
parts.body: The Inactive Users Email strategy is useful for getting users who signed up for your service but forgot about it to interact with your product again. Many SaaS or app companies face the issue of inactive users, and a direct way to engage them is through engagement-driven emails. These emails serve to remind users of your service and motivate them to come back, thus potentially increasing app usage and customer retention. To implement this, you need to track user behavior and use tools that allow you to send automated emails to inactive users. First, sign up for an automation tool to help manage these emails. Consider what kind of messages would re-engage users, and set up email campaigns that automatically trigger based on user inactivity. Doing this can help in reactivating forgotten users who might become valuable customers again.

parts.title: Boost Engagement with User-Generated Content
parts.body: User-generated content is a great way to boost engagement and reach new audiences, especially on social media like Facebook and Twitter. This strategy involves content produced by your followers, which also helps illustrate brand loyalty. Some companies run these campaigns for three main reasons: strengthening brand reputation, leveraging user experiences, and requiring minimal ongoing management after setup. To implement a User-Generated Content (UGC) campaign, start by deciding on a concept that focuses on your products and target customers. Look at successful examples like Warby Parker or Starbucks for inspiration. Once planned, spread the word about your campaign and encourage loyal customers to participate, which will help stimulate the campaign's momentum.

parts.title: The Win-Back Email Strategy
parts.body: ## The Win-Back Email The Win-Back Email is a strategy to re-engage former customers who have stopped buying from you. Smart business owners see the value in connecting with these past customers, realizing it's often easier to sell to people familiar with their brand. Win-Back Emails showcase new features, offer special deals, and include strong CTAs to persuade them to return. Step 1: Identify past customers who left 60-120 days ago. Step 2: Craft a persuasive email emphasizing new features and offers. Step 3: Send the email, analyze results, and adjust as needed. Tools like VERO and Customer.io can automate the process, helping you win back these valuable contacts.
